data.title: If You Invested $100 In Wells Fargo Stock 5 Years Ago, You Would Have This Much Today
data.description:
Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) has outperformed the market over the past 5 years by 4.99% on an annualized basis producing an average annual return of 17.14%. Currently, Wells Fargo has a market capitalization of $261.48 billion.

Buying $100 In WFC: If an investor had bought $100 of WFC stock 5 years ago, it would be worth $220.81 today based on a price of $84.55 for WFC at the time of writing.

Wells Fargo's Performance Over Last 5 Years

Finally -- what's the point of all this? The key insight to take from this article is to note how much of a difference compounded returns can make in your cash growth over a period of time.

This article was generated by Benzinga's automated content engine and reviewed by an editor.

data.title: Ginkgo Bioworks Pivots To AI And Robotics After Rough Quarter
data.description:
Ginkgo Bioworks (NYSE:DNA) shares are down following the company’s fourth-quarter and full-year 2025 financial report.

The stock’s decline comes as the company is focusing on investing in autonomous labs.

Divests Non-Core Business To Focus On Robotics

For the fourth quarter of 2025, Ginkgo Bioworks reported a strategic pivot towards robotics and AI, with CEO Jason Kelly emphasizing the company’s collaboration with the Department of Energy and OpenAI.

The company also announced plans to divest its biosecurity business to a consortium of investors for a minority stake, with the transaction expected to close in the first half of 2026, allowing Ginkgo to concentrate its resources on its autonomous labs initiative.

In addition, Ginkgo’s biosecurity business will operate as a standalone entity, aiming to enhance its growth potential with new investors.

This move is part of a broader strategy to capitalize on the increasing interest in defense technology and private capital markets, as stated by Kelly.

Ginkgo Bioworks Snapshot

Analyst View

“The combination of low visibility and transparency will be challenging for investors to swallow,” William Blair wrote in an investor note on Friday.

Ginkgo Bioworks is putting the pieces in place, according to William Blair analyst Matt Larew. The Biosecurity divestment/renewed focus on core Cell Engineering are steps in the right direction.

Still, as has been the case for several years, there needs to be tangible evidence that plans and promises translate into results for the stock to work.

William Blair reiterates an Underperform rating.

Technical Analysis

The stock is currently trading 18.13% below its 20-day simple moving average (SMA) and 12.5% below its 100-day SMA, indicating a bearish trend. Shares have decreased by 54.5% over the past 12 months and are currently positioned closer to their 52-week lows than highs.

The RSI is at 50.00, considered neutral territory, suggesting the stock is neither overbought nor oversold. Meanwhile, MACD is at -0.05, below its signal line at 0.10, indicating bearish pressure on the stock.

The combination of neutral RSI and bearish MACD suggests mixed momentum.

  • Key Resistance: $8.50
  • Key Support: $5.00

Analyst Consensus & Recent Actions: The stock carries a Hold Rating with an average price target of $169.73. Recent analyst moves include:

  • TD Cowen: Buy (Lowers Target to $12.00) (Jan. 8)

DNA Price Action: Ginkgo Bioworks shares were down 24.7% at $7.31 at last check on Friday, according to Benzinga Pro data.

Image: Shutterstock

data.title: EXCLUSIVE: Pokemon YouTuber Leonhart Opening Every Pack Ever Made To Celebrate 30th Anniversary – 'I Have To Go Massive'
data.description:
YouTuber Lee Steinfeld is best known to his fans around the world as Leonhart, one of the top Pokémon content creators.

His fans, known as the "Hart Squad," and other Pokémon aficionados will be tuning in to YouTube on Friday to watch one of his biggest videos ever to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the popular brand.

Benzinga recently caught up with Leonhart to hear about his memories of Pokémon as the brand turns 30.

• Nintendo Co shares are powering higher. Why are NTDOY shares rallying?

Pokémon Pack Opening

Coming shortly after news of a record sale of the Pikachu Illustrator card, Leonhart will put the spotlight on Pokémon cards of old and new.

"Nothing like this has been done before," Leonhart told Benzinga.

"30 years. I'm 39. It's been part of my life for most of it. I have to go massive."

A former lawyer by trade, Leonhart quit his job in 2017 to focus full-time on content creation around Pokémon. His YouTube channel, launched in 2014, surged in popularity alongside the recent growth of Pokémon, which may have started with the release of mobile game Pokémon Go in 2016.

Alongside his popularity, Leonhart made charity and giving back key to his full-time content creation, which included raising money for mental health support. His latest pack opening will be done to raise funds for charity.

"I'm giving away EVERY card I pull from EVERY pack of Pokémon cards ever made! Only need to donate $5 to the National Alliance on Mental Illness for a chance to win everything!" Leonhart tweeted with a link to the donation page.

Properly telling Benzinga that he likes to "open up shiny cardboard" in reference to Pokémon cards, Friday's opening could be one of the biggest the brand has ever seen. Leonhart's last opening of every pack in December 2023 ran nearly two hours in length and has around 2.5 million views on YouTube.

Nostalgia Carries Pokémon 

Leonhart told Benzinga that his first memory of Pokémon was the original Game Boy Pokémon Red and Pokémon Blue games and the popular animated television show, which predated the release of Pokémon cards in the U.S.

It's those memories that got him back into Pokémon over the years and led to his full-time efforts on YouTube.

"Nostalgia is one of the most powerful things and words in the entire world," Leonhart told Benzinga.

Leonhart said he's nearly speechless when he thinks about the ways he's celebrated Pokémon over the decades as the brand turns 30.

"You have generations of people that love Pokémon."

The content creator said new generations of fans fall in love with the brand, alongside existing fans falling back in love with it as new characters and products come out.

Photo courtesy of Leonhard

data.title: EXCLUSIVE: Pokémon 30th Anniversary Puts Focus On Brand, Nintendo Stake; YouTuber Leonhart Says 'Endless Possibilities' For Monetization
data.description:
Pokémon‘s decades-long popularity is gaining fresh momentum ahead of its 30th anniversary, fueled by record card prices and a Super Bowl spotlight. YouTuber Leonhart tells Benzinga the brand is far from peaking.

30th Anniversary Creates Monetization Opportunities

Pokémon may have surprised fans by running a commercial during Super Bowl LX, which featured celebrities like Lady Gaga. Leonhart says the ad could draw attention, particularly from Lady Gaga fans.

"Nothing is as big as it can get," Leonhart told Benzinga of the brand's 30th anniversary.

Beyond the Super Bowl spotlight, Pokémon is expanding its reach through a wave of cross-promotions designed to tap into new audiences and reignite nostalgia.

Another wish of Leonhart is for General Mills (NYSE:GIS) to collaborate with Pokémon on cereal boxes once again.

Leonhart said The Pokémon Company takes time to get things moving on U.S. licensing deals because it’s based in Japan, but is moving faster than ever. But the YouTuber, who boasts nearly 2 million subscribers and is known for opening Pokémon card packs on stream, expects more monetization opportunities for the brand’s co-owners due to the anniversary.

Game Freak, Creatures and Nintendo (OTC:NTDOY) co-own The Pokémon Company as part of a joint venture.

Pokémon can also choose to deliberately wait before releasing new products and partnerships, given its lasting power.

"Nostalgia is one of the most powerful things and words in the entire world."  

While Pokémon games are currently exclusive to Nintendo consoles, Leonhart said he could imagine the games someday coming to PlayStation consoles for Sony (NYSE:SONY).

When asked about demand for The Pokémon Company, should the company ever go public, Leonhart said interest "would be astronomical."

The closest thing to investing in the brand right now is buying rare cards or sealed card products, Leonhart says.

Pokémon Card Records and Growth

Demand for Pokémon cards has been heating up in recent years. The brand just celebrated a new record with the $16.5 million sale of a rare Pikachu Illustrator card, previously owned by Logan Paul.

Leonhart said the record sale gives the brand more legitimacy to big investors who may not have paid close attention to Pokémon over other collectibles or sports cards.

Outside of collecting something like the Pikachu Illustrator card, Leonhart singled out one of the most well-known cards as the gem for collectors, or the "Mona Lisa of Pokémon." The YouTuber said the PSA 10-graded 1st-Edition Base Set Charizard is the key collectible.

"Everyone knows that one, but not everyone can have that one," Leonhart told Benzinga.

The content creator said that fans are also after collecting their favorite Pokémon characters or the cards with the coolest artwork, using the made-up word "gorgeoustry" to describe some of the card images.

Leonhart tells Benzinga he owns a rare PSA 10 Charizard that he bought for $18,500 when "Pokémon Go" came out in 2016. He later had the card's illustrator Mitsuhiro Arita sign it in what could make a one-of-a-kind collectible he never plans on parting with.

"Pokémon is working on fixing this problem."

Leonhart said the company has also invested in new printing facilities, which could support higher output as Pokémon works to avoid overprinting while still meeting demand for popular sets and high-value chase cards.

"It's tough now, but it's gonna get better."

Photo courtesy of Leonhart

data.title: What's Going On With CoreWeave Stock Today?
data.description:
CoreWeave Inc. (NASDAQ:CRWV) shares fell in premarket trading Friday after the AI cloud provider issued lighter-than-expected first-quarter revenue guidance.

  • CoreWeave shares are trending. Where are CRWV shares going?

The company posted fourth-quarter revenue of $1.57 billion, narrowly topping Wall Street’s $1.55 billion projection, but its near-term outlook disappointed investors.

Needham analyst Mike Cikos reiterated a Hold rating on the stock.

CoreWeave Guidance Trails Expectations

Heavy Investment Cycle

Agrawal said the company expanded its revolving credit facility to $2.5 billion. CoreWeave secured more than $18 billion in debt and equity financing during 2025.

The company also announced a $2 billion investment from Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA) tied to an expanded commercial partnership.

Agrawal said the company lowered its weighted average interest rate by 300 basis points in 2025.

He added that the reduction represents nearly $700 million in annualized interest savings. CoreWeave faces no major debt maturities until 2029, excluding amortizing contract-backed obligations.

CapEx Surge And Capacity Growth

The company plans capital expenditures between $30 billion and $35 billion in 2026.

That spending more than doubles 2025 investment levels. Management expects active power capacity to exceed 1.7 gigawatts by year-end, up from 850 megawatts across 43 data centers.

CoreWeave reported a contracted revenue backlog of $66.8 billion entering 2026.

Agrawal said, "Contracted customer demand, deep strategic partnerships, active infrastructure deployment, industry-leading capabilities, and a thoughtful approach to capital markets give us the confidence to put these numbers forward."

The company expects to exit 2026 with annualized run-rate revenue between $17 billion and $19 billion.

It projects that the figure will surpass $30 billion by the end of 2027.

CRWV Price Action: CoreWeave shares are trading lower by about 18% to $80.12 at last check on Friday.

Image: Shutterstock
